um and then it yeah that's the first image there and then in the second image you can see how
our products streamline this process and remove the need for software engineers to provision the environment so as a user
you can open up earth on demand browse through imagery collections select a date time range
an area of interest a cloud cover percentage and it'll return all the imagery that that meets your criteria then you can
copy your query into earth ai notebooks read that imagery into a raster frame which is just a spark
data frame consisting of raster data as i said before and perform all types of geospatial
analytics some examples are you can do local map
algebra for computing vegetation indices you can join your imagery with a vector data source and perform zonal map
algebra or aggregate your data across different areas of interest we have masking capabilities so you can
mask out cloudy or low quality pixels you can join your imagery with other imagery collections we have a raster
function raster joint function that handles the resampling and reprojection between image collections
there's a machine learning libraries installed so you can run your imagery through classification regression and clustering algorithms
and we have chipping capabilities to select small tiles of imagery for deep learning and computer vision purposes
and it's also possible to write out your imagery to different formats or view it in a slipping map with your images overlaid on a base map
we've tried to develop the platform and make it useful for all types of of purposes from from someone who just

working with this type of data and trying to develop models that will generalize over large areas
one one particular project is a computer vision model we built to detect large-scale solar farms we used
sentinel-2 imagery for this project so 10 to 20 meter resolution we had some
location data of solar farms in the u.s that we used as training data for our model but at this at the time we were unable to
find any training data outside of the u.s so we decided to deploy the model over
china because they're a big player in the solar energy industry so we figured we could find some solar farms there and we wanted to
test out how well our model generalized we did find about a thousand solar
arrays that were previously unknown at least to us but we also got a lot of false positives in our predictions
as you can see in these examples the model tend to do better over drier desert regions than wetter coastal
areas where there's a lot of water vapor in the atmosphere that created a haze we found that crop fields and tennis
courts at lower resolution look pretty similar to solar farms so we ended up adding these as negative examples in future iterations
of the model and the model also did much better in in desert regions because there was a high contrast between the panels and
the surrounding land whereas in green or forested areas they the panels kind of tended to blend in it was
difficult for the model to pick them out yeah this is fascinating to me and i

given droughts and changing weather patterns we were interested in exploring change
detection and the effects of of climate change and food insecurity in a country that may be in need of food
assistance programs using earth observing imagery and machine learning and we chose zambia because they're they
were ranked fifth worst in the 2018 global hunger index and they've been severely impacted by climate change
zambia is a landlocked country where agriculture supports the livelihoods of of 85 of the population and most farmers
rely on rainfall to irrigate their crops so they're especially vulnerable to weather fluctuations
um after we selected zambia we found out that publicly available ground truth data in
zambia didn't exist we did however have a geo-referenced ground truth crop data
for the u.s so we decided to train our model with u.s training data and score the model in zambia as you can see in this
architecture diagram to help with model generalizability we tried to pick
regions in the u.s as our training data with similar characteristics to zambia
such as similar climate biome weather patterns soil composition and a similar
mix of crops and we tried to make it as much of an apples to apples comparison as we could
but in the end we were still extrapolating to a different region in a different hemisphere the climate's not exactly the same
because the seasons in zambia don't follow like what we have they have more of a tropical climate so
it's rainy and dry seasons instead of cold and warm which definitely affects how crops grow
and also one thing we noticed was that the way they planted crops in some in zambia is not really the same as it
is here in zambia farmers tended to have smaller fields of mixed crops
and there's a lot of small gardens that are just supporting it one or two families whereas in the u.s our crop fields tend
to be very large and homogeneous so these these differences made it really hard to generalize the model

representative sample to have a reliable robust model there's there's really no way around that with
the zambia crop model we tried to match the training and scoring regions as much as we could and we still had a lot of problems with
generalizability there's a real lack of ground truth training data outside of the us and in european
countries and and that's a problem because we need diverse training data to train good generalizable models in the solar
farm project we used some human in the loop techniques to help with with generalizability we went through
several iterations of the model where we manually verified and hand labeled farms using a
semi-supervised approach so we we trained the model and then scored it on a large region and went
through model predictions and added false positives as negative examples to increase the size of the training data
and help the model correct its mistakes and learning patterns and then we retrain the model and repeated this
process several times and this requires a big manual labeling effort
which can be pretty tedious so we started developing partnerships with data labeling companies to outsource this work and it definitely
